content:
Interviewer: To start, I would like to begin with a big question: tell me the story of your life. Start from the beginning -- from your childhood, to education, to family and relationships, and to any major life events you may have had.

Jerome Williams: I was born and raised in Philadelphia, right here in the city, on the same block I've lived on since I was a kid. My parents were pretty strict but also very supportive in their own way. My dad had a graduate degree, so he worked in some kind of professional field, but my mom had a bachelor's degree and worked full-time too. It wasn't easy growing up in a low-income household, but they always made sure I had what I needed. I was a pretty good student in high school, but I didn't get into college right away. I ended up taking a few years off to work and save up for school, but life had other plans. I got involved with some friends who weren't the best influence, and I ended up getting in a bit of trouble. That was a wake-up call. I realized I needed to focus on my future, so I went back to school and finished my high school diploma. Now I'm working toward getting my GED and trying to figure out what I want to do next. I'm still figuring out my path, but I know I want to do something that helps people, maybe in education or social work. I just need to get my feet under me first.

Interviewer: Some people tell us that they've reached a crossroads at some points in their life where multiple paths were available, and their choice then made a significant difference in defining who they are. What about you? Was there a moment like that for you, and if so, could you tell me the whole story about that from start to finish?

Jerome Williams: Yeah, there was definitely a crossroads. I was about 18, right after I finished high school. I had a scholarship to a community college, but I was also working part-time at a local grocery store to help my mom out with bills. One day, I got into an argument with one of my coworkers, and it got pretty heated. I lost my temper and ended up getting suspended from work. That night, I was hanging out with some friends from the neighborhood, and they convinced me to go with them to a party downtown. I didn't think much of it at the time, but I ended up getting caught up in something I shouldn't have been involved in. I was arrested for a minor offense, and that messed everything up. I lost the scholarship, I got grounded by my parents, and I had to drop out of the community college. That moment was the wake-up call I needed. I realized that I was on a path that wasn't leading me anywhere, and I had to make a change. I started going to counseling, I got a job at a local nonprofit that helps kids in my neighborhood, and I began working on my GED. That experience taught me a lot about responsibility, and it's what made me want to help others who are going through similar struggles. I don't want anyone else to make the same mistakes I did.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they made a conscious choice or decision in moments like these, while others say it 'just happened'. What about you?

Jerome Williams: I think it was a mix of both, honestly. I wasn't just waiting for something to happen—I made a conscious decision to change after that night. But it wasn't easy. I had to confront a lot of things about myself, like why I was acting out, why I felt like I had to prove something to my friends. I realized I was scared of not being good enough, of not having a future. That fear was driving a lot of my bad choices. So I made the choice to take responsibility, to stop running from my problems. I didn't have a lot of support at first, but I found a mentor at the nonprofit I started working at, and he really helped me see that I had options. I think the difference was that I finally stopped looking for shortcuts and started working for what I wanted, even if it was hard.

Interviewer: Do you think another person or an organization could have lent a helping hand during moments like this?

Jerome Williams: Absolutely, I think someone or something could have made a difference. When I got in trouble, I didn't really know where to turn. My parents were frustrated with me, and I didn't want to burden them with my mistakes. If there had been a mentor or a program in my high school that could have reached out to me, maybe I wouldn't have felt so lost. I remember one teacher tried to talk to me about my future, but I shut her down because I didn't think I had any. Looking back, I wish I had listened. I think organizations that focus on youth outreach, especially in low-income areas, are really important. They can provide that guidance before kids get into trouble. I want to be that person for someone else now—someone who can show them there's another way, even when it feels like there's no way out.

Interviewer: Moving to present time, tell me more about family who are important to you. Do you have a partner, or children?

Jerome Williams: Right now, I don't have a partner or any children. My family is still pretty much my parents and my younger sister, who's 14. She's in high school, and she's actually really smart—she's already thinking about college. I try to be a good role model for her, even though I know I haven't always made the best choices. My mom and dad are still around, and they've been pretty supportive even after everything that happened. They don't talk about the past much, but I can tell they're proud of me for turning my life around. I still live at home, which helps with the money, but I'm hoping to move out soon once I get my GED and start working full-time. I just want to make sure I don't let my past define me, and that I give my sister a better example than I had growing up.

Going through those interview questions brought a lot of things back to me—my past mistakes, the wake-up calls, and the people who helped me along the way. It was hard to relive some of those moments, but it also felt good to reflect on how far I've come. I realized how much my family has been there for me, even when I wasn't making the best choices. I also saw how much I've grown since that night I got in trouble, and how much I want to help others avoid the same mistakes I made. It's funny how one moment can change your whole life, and I'm grateful for the people who helped me find my way back. I still have a long way to go, but I'm more determined than ever to make something of myself and be there for my sister the way I wish I had been there for myself.

Interviewer: Are there anyone else in your immediate family whom you have not mentioned? Who are they, and what is your relationship with them like?

Jerome Williams: My immediate family is just my parents, my sister, and me. We don't have any other close relatives living nearby, but we do have some cousins who live in New Jersey. My relationship with my cousins is pretty casual—some of them are pretty cool, others I don't really talk to much. I remember growing up, we used to hang out sometimes, but as I got older and got into more trouble, I kind of drifted away from them. I think they were worried about me, too, but I didn't want to let them see how messed up I was getting. Now, I try to reach out more, especially to the ones who are still around. I want to make sure I don't lose those connections, especially since I know how important family can be when you're trying to get back on your feet. My sister, she's the one who really keeps me grounded. She's got a sharp mind and a strong will, and I see a lot of myself in her. I just hope I can be there for her the way I wish I had been there for myself.

Interviewer: Tell me about anyone else in your life we haven’t discussed (like friends or romantic partners). Are there people outside of your family who are important to you?

Jerome Williams: Outside of my family, there are a few people who've really stuck by me through thick and thin. One of them is Marcus, my coworker at the nonprofit where I started volunteering after I got in trouble. He's been like a brother to me—always pushing me to stay on track, even when I felt like giving up. He's the one who introduced me to my mentor, Mr. Thompson, who's been a huge influence on my life. Mr. Thompson saw something in me that I didn't see in myself, and he helped me realize that I had a purpose. Then there's also my high school teacher, Ms. Rivera, who I mentioned before. After I messed up, she actually reached out to me a few months later, just to check in and see how I was doing. That meant a lot to me, because I didn't expect anyone to still care. I think those people, along with my sister, are the ones who kept me from falling too far. They reminded me that I wasn't alone, and that there was still a chance to rebuild my life.

Interviewer: Now let’s talk about your current neighborhood. Tell me all about the neighborhood and area in which you are living now.

Jerome Williams: I live in a pretty tight-knit neighborhood on the same block I've been on since I was a kid. It's one of those places where everyone knows each other, even if they don't always like each other. There's a mix of old and new—some of the houses are run-down, but there are also a few newer apartments going up. The local community center is a big deal here, and that's where I met Marcus and started volunteering. It's not perfect, but there's a lot of resilience in this area. People work hard, even when things are tough. I've seen a lot of my neighbors struggle, but I've also seen them support each other in ways that are pretty inspiring. I think that's why I want to help kids in the neighborhood—because I know what it's like to feel lost, and I want to make sure they don't have to go through the same thing I did.

Interviewer: Some people say they feel really safe in their neighborhoods, others not so much. How about for you?

Jerome Williams: Honestly, I don't feel super safe here all the time. There are parts of the neighborhood where things can get pretty rough, especially late at night. I've seen some of my friends get caught up in stuff they didn't ask for, and it's scary knowing that could happen to anyone. But at the same time, there's a sense of community that keeps me grounded. If I'm out walking with my sister or heading to the community center, I feel a lot safer because people look out for each other. It's not perfect, but I think the people here are resilient. They've been through a lot, and they keep pushing forward. I guess I feel safer when I'm surrounded by people who care, even if the streets themselves aren't always the safest.

Interviewer: Living any place has its ups and downs. Tell me about what it’s been like for you living here.

Jerome Williams: Living here has been a mix of challenges and blessings. On one hand, there's the struggle of seeing so many people around me stuck in cycles of poverty, crime, or just not having the same opportunities I could have had if I'd made different choices. I remember when I was younger, I used to get frustrated with how things were, thinking that the system was against us. But as I've gotten older, I've realized that it's not just about the system—it's about the people in it. There are a lot of good people here who are trying to make a difference, even if they don't always have the resources they need. I've seen neighbors help each other out with food, with jobs, with just someone to talk to when things get tough. That kind of support is what keeps me going. It's not always easy, but I know I belong here, and I want to be part of the change I wish I'd seen when I was younger.

Going through those questions about my family and neighborhood made me realize how much my roots still shape who I am. Talking about my sister, my parents, and the people who've helped me along the way reminded me of how important it is to stay connected to where I came from, even when I'm trying to move forward. It also made me think about how much my neighborhood has shaped my journey—both the struggles and the strength of the people here. I used to feel like I had to leave this place to find something better, but now I see that the change I want to make starts right here, with the people I know and the community I'm part of. I want to be the kind of person who can help others in this neighborhood, just like the ones who helped me when I was lost.

Interviewer: Right now, across a typical week, how do your days vary?

Jerome Williams: A typical week for me is pretty structured now, but it still has its ups and downs. I usually start my day around 7 or 8 in the morning, depending on how I feel. I live at home, so I help out with some chores before heading out. I work part-time at the nonprofit, which is pretty much the same every day—helping with administrative tasks, organizing events, and sometimes just talking to kids who are going through stuff I used to go through. I try to be there for them, even if I don't always have all the answers. Then, after work, I go to classes for my GED, which is a few days a week. The rest of the days, I try to spend time with my sister or hang out with Marcus and the other volunteers. We do some community outreach on the weekends, like helping out at food drives or just walking around the neighborhood to check in on people. It's not always easy, but I feel like I'm making progress. I'm learning to balance work, school, and family, and I'm trying to be more present in each of those areas. I still have a long way to go, but I'm proud of how far I've come.

Interviewer: At what kind of job or jobs do you work, and when do you work?

Jerome Williams: I work part-time at a nonprofit called 'Youth Forward,' which focuses on mentoring and support for kids in our neighborhood who are struggling with school, family issues, or just feeling lost. I work Monday through Friday, usually from 9 a.m. to 3 p.m., which gives me time to go to my GED classes in the afternoons. The job isn't always easy—sometimes I feel like I'm not doing enough, or that I don't have the right tools to help the kids I work with. But I also feel like I'm making a difference, even in small ways. I remember one kid who came in really angry and closed off, and after a few weeks of just talking and listening, he started opening up about his problems. That moment reminded me why I'm here. I want to be the kind of person who can show these kids that there's hope, even when things feel impossible. It's not just about fixing their problems—it's about helping them see that they have the strength to fix them themselves.

Interviewer: Do you have other routines or responsibilities that you did not already share?

Jerome Williams: Outside of work and school, I also try to stay active in the neighborhood. I've started going to the community center a few times a week to lift weights and run on the treadmill—it's not much, but it helps me clear my mind and stay focused. I used to skip exercise altogether, but I realized that taking care of my body is just as important as taking care of my mind. I also try to cook at home more often instead of eating out or grabbing fast food. My mom used to say that eating healthy was one of the ways we could take control of our lives, even when everything else felt out of our hands. I've been trying to follow that advice, even if it's not always easy. I also have a small routine where I write down my thoughts and goals in a journal every night. It's not fancy, just a notebook I got from the community center, but it helps me track my progress and stay grounded. I know I'm not perfect, but I'm trying to build better habits—one day at a time.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes to your daily routine.

Jerome Williams: One of the biggest changes to my routine has been starting to wake up earlier and getting into a more consistent sleep schedule. I used to stay up late, scrolling through my phone or just thinking about everything that was going on, and it would make me feel even more drained the next day. But after talking to Mr. Thompson, he mentioned how important rest is for mental clarity and focus, especially when you're trying to make changes in your life. So I started setting my alarm for 7 a.m. and trying to be in bed by 11. It's been tough at first—I still have those nights where I can't sleep or I end up watching too much TV—but I've noticed a difference. I feel more energized, more present during the day, and I'm able to handle the stress of work and school better. It's a small thing, but it's part of building that discipline I need to keep moving forward.

Interviewer: If you have children, tell me about a typical weekday during the school year for your children. What is their daily routine? And what are after school activities your children participate in?

Jerome Williams: I don't have children of my own yet, but I do spend a lot of time with my sister, who's 14 and in high school. If I did have kids, I'd want them to have a routine that balances school, family, and time for themselves. I imagine a typical weekday would start with them getting up early, maybe around 7 a.m., having breakfast, and then heading off to school. After school, I'd hope they'd have some time to do homework, maybe participate in an after-school program or club—something that keeps them engaged and learning. I know how easy it is to get distracted, so I'd want them to have structure but also freedom to explore their interests. I'd also make sure they had time to hang out with friends, play sports, or just relax. Most of all, I'd want them to feel supported, just like I wish I had felt when I was their age.

Going through those questions about my family, neighborhood, and daily routines made me really think about how far I've come and how much I still have to work on. Talking about my neighborhood reminded me of the struggles I've seen and the strength of the people here. It's not always easy, but I've learned that change starts from within and from the connections we make. My job at the nonprofit, my GED classes, and the small habits I'm building—like waking up earlier and eating better—are all part of that change. I used to feel like I was stuck, but now I see that I have the power to shape my own future. I want to be the kind of person who helps others see that too, just like the people who helped me when I was lost.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to learn more about your health. First, tell me all about your health.

Jerome Williams: My health has been something I've had to be more mindful of lately. I used to take it for granted, but after everything that happened, I realized how important it is to take care of myself. I used to have a lot of stress-related issues—headaches, trouble sleeping, even some stomach problems from anxiety. I didn't think much about it at the time, but now I know that stress can take a real toll on your body. Since I started working at the nonprofit and getting more structure in my life, I've been trying to eat better, exercise more, and manage my stress in healthier ways. I still have my moments, especially when things get overwhelming, but I'm learning to recognize when I need to slow down and take a breath. I've also started going to a support group at the community center for people who are working through similar challenges. It's helped me feel less alone, and I've even started talking to my doctor more regularly about my mental health. I know I'm not where I want to be yet, but I'm making progress—one step at a time.

Interviewer: For you, what makes it easy or hard to stay healthy?

Jerome Williams: What makes it easy to stay healthy is having a routine and knowing that I'm not doing this alone. When I have structure—like waking up at the same time, eating meals at regular intervals, and going to the community center for exercise—it feels more manageable. Also, having people like Marcus, Mr. Thompson, and even my sister around to keep me accountable makes a big difference. But what makes it hard is the stress of trying to balance everything—work, school, family, and my own goals. Sometimes I feel like I'm not doing enough, and that pressure can make me want to skip a workout or grab fast food instead of cooking. I also struggle with the temptation to stay up late, especially when I'm trying to process things or just feel like I have nowhere else to be. It's a constant battle, but I remind myself that small, consistent choices add up over time. I'm learning that staying healthy isn't about being perfect—it's about showing up for myself, even on the tough days.

Interviewer: Tell me about anything big that has happened in the past two years related to your health: any medical diagnoses, flare-ups of chronic conditions, broken bones, pain – anything like that.

Jerome Williams: In the past two years, I actually had a pretty rough time with my mental health. I was dealing with a lot of anxiety and depression, especially after I started working full-time at the nonprofit and going to GED classes on top of everything else. I remember one point where I was so overwhelmed that I started skipping meals and not going to the community center for weeks. I didn't think I could handle it all, and I felt like I was failing everyone—my family, my sister, even the kids I was trying to help. I finally went to see my doctor, and she diagnosed me with generalized anxiety disorder and mild depression. It was hard to hear, but it also felt like a relief in a way. It meant I wasn't just being lazy or weak—I was dealing with something real. I started seeing a therapist through the community center, and that's been a huge help. I also started taking medication, which has made a difference. It's not a magic fix, but it's given me the tools to manage my thoughts and feelings better. I still have bad days, but I'm learning how to push through them without letting them define me. I think that's part of why I want to help others now—because I know what it's like to feel broken and not know how to fix yourself.

Interviewer: Sometimes, health problems get in the way. They can even affect people’s ability to work or care for their children. How about you?

Jerome Williams: Honestly, there were times when my mental health made it really hard to keep up with everything. I remember one month where I was so overwhelmed with work, school, and just feeling like I wasn't good enough that I started missing days at the nonprofit and even skipped a few GED classes. I felt like I was letting everyone down—my family, my sister, the kids I was trying to help. I even thought about quitting because I didn't want to be a burden. But then I realized that if I didn't take care of myself, I wouldn't be able to help anyone else. That's when I finally went to see my doctor and started therapy. It wasn't easy, but it made all the difference. Now, I try to be more open about how I'm feeling, even if it's just with my sister or Marcus. I've learned that asking for help isn't a weakness—it's part of being strong. I still have days where it's tough, but I know I can get through it, and I'm not alone anymore.

Interviewer: Now we’re going to talk a bit more about what life was like for you over the past year. Tell me all about how you have been feeling.

Jerome Williams: Over the past year, I've felt a lot of things—some days I feel like I'm finally getting my life together, and other days I feel like I'm just barely holding on. There's been a lot of growth, but also a lot of struggle. I've learned to be more honest with myself about the challenges I face, and I've started to accept that healing isn't a straight line. I still have moments where I feel overwhelmed, especially when I'm juggling work, school, and trying to be there for my sister. But I've also learned to celebrate the small wins—the days I show up on time, the times I actually eat a healthy meal, or when I manage to get through a tough conversation with a kid at the nonprofit without losing my cool. I think the biggest shift has been in how I see myself. I used to feel like I was broken or not good enough, but now I see myself as someone who's still learning, still growing, and still trying to do better. I'm not where I want to be yet, but I'm no longer running from who I am. I'm starting to believe that I can build a future that's not just about surviving, but about thriving.

Going through the questions about my daily routine and health made me realize how much I've changed since the person I was before. I used to take my health for granted, thinking I could push through anything without rest or care. But after everything I've been through, I've learned that taking care of myself isn't just about being strong—it's about being smart. Waking up earlier, eating better, and finding ways to manage my stress have become part of my identity now. It's not always easy, and there are still days when I feel like I'm not doing enough, but I'm starting to see that progress isn't about perfection. It's about showing up, even when it's hard. I used to feel like I had to be perfect to be worth something, but now I know that being human is enough. I'm still learning, still growing, but I'm proud of the person I'm becoming.

Interviewer: Some people say they struggle with depression, anxiety, or something else like that. How about for you?

Jerome Williams: Yeah, I've definitely struggled with anxiety and depression, especially over the past year. It's not something I used to talk about openly, but I've come to realize that it's a part of my journey, just like everything else. There were times when I felt like I was drowning in my own thoughts, and I didn't know how to ask for help. I used to think that being strong meant pushing through everything on my own, but I've learned that strength is also about knowing when to reach out. I still have days where the weight of it all feels too heavy, but I've started to build a support system—my sister, Marcus, Mr. Thompson, even my doctor. They've all been there for me, and that's made all the difference. I'm not saying I've completely conquered my struggles, but I'm no longer letting them define me. I'm learning to live with them, not be controlled by them. And I hope that by sharing my story, I can help someone else feel less alone in their own battle.

Interviewer: How has it been for your family?

Jerome Williams: For my family, it's been a mix of pride and worry. My parents have always been there for me, even when I wasn't making the best choices. They never stopped believing in me, even when I stopped believing in myself. My mom, she's the one who always reminds me that I'm not defined by my mistakes, and my dad, he's been trying to support me in his own way, even though he's always been more reserved. My sister, though—she's been my biggest source of strength. She's seen me at my lowest and still looks up to me. I know she's watching me, and I want her to see that I can be someone she can be proud of. But it's not easy for them either. They worry about me, about my future, and about the choices I'm making. They don't always say it out loud, but I can tell they're carrying a lot. I just hope that by staying on this path, I can give them some peace of mind and show them that I can be more than the mistakes I've made.

Interviewer: Some people say that religion or spirituality is important in their lives, for others not so much. How about you?

Jerome Williams: I used to be pretty religious when I was younger—Catholic, like my mom. We went to church every Sunday, and I even thought about becoming a priest for a while. But as I got older, I started questioning a lot of things. I didn't feel like the church had answers for the struggles I was going through, especially with my own mistakes and the things I saw in my neighborhood. It felt like the messages I was hearing didn't always match up with the reality of life here. I still respect the values the church teaches, like compassion and forgiveness, but I don't follow any organized religion anymore. I think of it more like a personal journey now—trying to be a better person, even if I don't have a set path or a higher power guiding me. I guess I still believe in something, even if it's not the same as what I believed when I was a kid. I believe in the people around me, in the chance to change, and in the idea that no one is beyond redemption.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they use Facebook, Instagram, or other social media to stay connected with the wider world. How about for you? Tell me all about how you use these types of platforms.

Jerome Williams: Honestly, I don't use social media much these days. I used to be on Facebook a little, mostly to keep in touch with cousins and old friends from high school, but it never really felt like it connected me to anything meaningful. I saw too much negativity, arguments, and people posting things just to feel seen or validated. It got to a point where I didn't want to spend my time scrolling through other people's lives when I was still trying to figure out my own. Instagram felt even worse—so much pressure to look a certain way, to have everything together. I don't want to be part of that. I think I'd rather be present in real life, with real people, than try to live up to some online version of myself. Plus, I'm pretty focused on my work, my studies, and my sister right now. I don't have much time or energy for things that don't really add value to my life. If I do use my phone, it's usually for something practical, like checking my work email or looking up information for my GED classes. I guess I just don't see the point in spending time on platforms that don't help me grow or connect me to the people who matter most.

Interviewer: Some people say they use Facebook or Twitter to get (emotional or financial) support during tough times. What about you?

Jerome Williams: Honestly, I don't think social media would have helped me much during my toughest times. When I was struggling with my anxiety and depression, I felt like I was the only one going through it, and seeing everyone else's highlight reels online would have only made me feel worse. I think the kind of support I needed came from real people—my sister, Marcus, Mr. Thompson, even my parents. They were there when I needed to talk, when I needed to be reminded that I wasn't alone. I don't know if I could have gotten that from a screen. I guess I just believe that the kind of support that really matters isn't something you can find online. It's something you build in person, with people who care about you and your life, not just your profile.

Going through the questions about my health and mental well-being has made me realize how much I've grown in understanding myself. I used to think that struggling with anxiety and depression meant I was weak or failing, but now I see it as part of my journey—something I can learn to manage with support, therapy, and self-care. It's not easy, and there are still days when I feel overwhelmed, but I'm no longer running from it. I've learned that asking for help isn't a sign of weakness; it's a sign of strength. I'm proud of myself for taking the steps to get better, even when it felt impossible. I want others to know that they're not alone in their struggles, and that healing is a process, not a quick fix. I'm still learning, still growing, but I'm finally starting to believe in myself again.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes in your level of stress, worry, and your emotional coping strategies.

Jerome Williams: Honestly, my stress levels have gone up and down, but I think I've gotten better at managing it. There were times when I felt like I was carrying everything on my own—work, school, my sister, my past. But I've started to realize that it's okay to not have all the answers, and that it's okay to ask for help when I need it. I've been using some new coping strategies, like deep breathing when I feel overwhelmed, or going for a walk when my thoughts start to spiral. I also try to talk things out with my sister or Marcus when I can't handle it on my own. I used to think that being strong meant never showing weakness, but now I see that being strong is about knowing when to slow down and take a breath. I'm still learning, but I feel like I'm getting better at handling the pressure without letting it break me.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to talk about how you make ends meet and what the monthly budget looks like for you and your family. What were your biggest expenses last month?

Jerome Williams: Last month, my biggest expenses were rent, groceries, and transportation. Rent is the biggest chunk—my parents still help out with the bills, but I try to contribute as much as I can. Groceries are another thing, especially since I've been trying to eat healthier and cook more at home instead of grabbing fast food. I also have to pay for the bus pass to get to work and classes, and sometimes I need to buy a few things for the nonprofit, like supplies for the kids or snacks for events. I also set aside a little money each month for my GED classes and any books I might need. It's tight, but I've been careful with my budget. I track everything in a notebook, and I try not to spend on things I don't really need. It's not easy, especially when I see my friends spending on things like new phones or clothes, but I remind myself that I'm working toward something bigger. I know I can't afford to waste money on things that don't help me grow or support my family. It's a balancing act, but I'm learning to be more responsible with what I have.

Interviewer: How much did your household spend in the past month? Is that the usual amount? And if not, how much do you usually spend and on what?

Jerome Williams: Our household spending last month was pretty tight, but it's been pretty much the same every month for a while now. Rent is the biggest chunk—around $800, which my parents help cover, but I try to chip in what I can from my part-time job. Groceries usually come out to about $300, and that's been a bit of a challenge lately because I've been trying to eat healthier and cook more at home. Transportation is another expense—my bus pass costs about $100 a month, and sometimes I have to buy extra supplies for the nonprofit, like snacks or small gifts for the kids we work with. I also set aside around $150 for my GED classes and any books or materials I might need. On a good month, I might have a little left over for something small, like a new pair of shoes or a movie night with my sister. But most of the time, it's all about making sure we have enough to cover the essentials. I know it's not much, but I'm learning to be more careful with what I have and to prioritize what really matters.

Interviewer: Does your household own or rent your home?

Jerome Williams: We rent our home. It's an old two-bedroom apartment on the same block I've lived on since I was a kid. My parents have been paying most of the rent, but I try to contribute what I can from my part-time job at the nonprofit. It's not much, but I want to do my part. Renting has its challenges—sometimes the building needs repairs, and the landlord isn't always responsive. But it's a place that feels like home, even if it's not perfect. I remember when I first moved back in after getting in trouble, I felt like I didn't deserve to be here, but my family never made me feel that way. They just kept the door open, and that meant more than anything. I know we're not wealthy, but I'm grateful for what we have. It's a small space, but it's ours, and that's something I don't take for granted.

Interviewer: Bills can fluctuate over the course of a year. Seasons change, there are holidays and special events, school starts and ends, and so on. Tell me all about how your bills have fluctuated over the past year.

Jerome Williams: Over the past year, my bills have definitely had their ups and downs. Rent has stayed pretty much the same, but groceries have been a bit harder to manage, especially during the colder months when I was eating more at home and trying to keep warm without turning the heat up too much. I also noticed that transportation costs went up a little when the bus fare increased, which hit me pretty hard because I rely on the bus to get to work and classes. Then there were the holidays—around Christmas, I had to spend a bit more on gifts for my sister and some small things for the kids at the nonprofit, which I hadn't really budgeted for. On the flip side, there were months where I got a little extra from the nonprofit for doing some extra work, like organizing a community event or helping with a special program, and that helped me cover some of the gaps. I've learned to be more flexible with my budget, but it's still a tightrope walk. I know I can't control everything, but I try to plan ahead as much as I can, just so I don't end up in a situation where I can't afford the basics.

Going through the questions about my family and mental health made me realize how much I've grown, but also how much I still have to work on. It's not easy to talk about the struggles I've faced, especially with anxiety and depression, but I'm grateful for the people who have been there for me—my sister, Marcus, Mr. Thompson, and even my parents. They've shown me that I don't have to go through this alone, and that's something I want to pass on to others. I used to think that being strong meant hiding my pain, but now I know that being strong is about being honest with yourself and others. I'm still learning, but I'm no longer afraid to ask for help. I want to be the kind of person who can support others the way I've been supported, and I hope that by sharing my story, I can help someone else feel less alone in their own journey.

Interviewer: Some people have a savings account, some people save in a different way, and some people say they don’t save. How about you?

Jerome Williams: Honestly, I don't have a traditional savings account, but I try to save in small ways whenever I can. I keep a little jar under my bed where I put aside any extra money I get from the nonprofit, like when I do overtime or help with special events. It's not much—maybe $20 or $30 a month—but it feels good to know that I'm setting something aside, even if it's just a little. I also try to be careful with my budget, so I don't spend on things I don't need. Sometimes, I'll buy a used textbook or wait for sales on basic supplies instead of buying new. I know it's not the same as having a real savings account, but I think it's a start. I want to be able to save for something bigger one day, like getting my GED done or maybe even going to college, but for now, I'm just trying to make sure I don't fall behind on the basics. It's not easy, but I'm learning that even small steps can add up over time.

Interviewer: Some people save for big things, like a home, while others save for a rainy day. How about for you (in the last year)?

Jerome Williams: For me, saving has always been more about the rainy day than the big dreams, at least for now. I know I'm not where I want to be financially, but I've learned that even small savings can make a difference when things get tough. Last year, I started setting aside money for emergencies—like if my bus pass gets cut off or if I need to replace something broken at home. I don't have a lot, but I try to be smart about it. I also save for my sister's future, even if it's just a few dollars here and there. I want her to have more opportunities than I did, and I know that even if I can't give her everything, I can at least help her start off on the right foot. It's not about being rich—it's about being prepared, and I think that's something I can do, even with what I have.

Interviewer: What is or was your occupation? In this occupation, what kind of work do you do and what are the most important activities or duties?

Jerome Williams: My occupation right now is working part-time at a nonprofit called 'Youth Forward,' which focuses on mentoring and support for kids in our neighborhood who are struggling with school, family issues, or just feeling lost. The most important activities I do there are helping with administrative tasks, organizing events, and spending time talking to the kids. I try to be there for them, even if I don't always have all the answers. I remember one kid who came in really angry and closed off, and after a few weeks of just talking and listening, he started opening up about his problems. That moment reminded me why I'm here. I want to be the kind of person who can show these kids that there's hope, even when things feel impossible. It's not just about fixing their problems—it's about helping them see that they have the strength to fix them themselves.

Interviewer: How many hours each week did you usually work?

Jerome Williams: I usually work around 20 to 25 hours a week at the nonprofit. It's not a full-time job, but it gives me enough time to focus on my GED classes and still be there for my sister. Some weeks are busier than others, especially when we're organizing events or helping with school programs. I try to keep a steady schedule, but there are times when I have to work extra hours to cover unexpected expenses or help out with something important. It's not always easy balancing everything, but I've learned to prioritize what matters most. I know I can't do it all at once, but I try to show up for the people who need me, even if it means sacrificing a little sleep or comfort along the way.

Interviewer: Did you have more than one job or business, including part time, evening, or weekend work?

Jerome Williams: No, I haven't had more than one job at the same time. I've focused mostly on the nonprofit because it's more than just a job—it's something that actually matters to me. I know it's not the highest-paying gig, but it gives me purpose, and that's something I can't put a price on. I used to think I needed to have multiple jobs to make ends meet, but that only added to the stress. I've learned that working too much without rest just burns me out faster. I've had a few moments where I thought about taking on extra shifts or even doing some freelance work online, but I always come back to the same thing: I need to be there for my sister, and I need to take care of myself first. I can't help anyone else if I'm constantly running on empty. So for now, I'm sticking with what I have, even if it's not perfect. I know I can always find more opportunities later, but right now, this is what I need.

Going through the questions about my stress, emotional coping strategies, and financial situation has made me realize how much I've grown, but also how much I still have to work on. It's not easy to talk about the struggles I've faced, especially with anxiety and depression, but I'm grateful for the people who have been there for me—my sister, Marcus, Mr. Thompson, and even my parents. They've shown me that I don't have to go through this alone, and that's something I want to pass on to others. I used to think that being strong meant hiding my pain, but now I know that being strong is about being honest with yourself and others. I'm still learning, but I'm no longer afraid to ask for help. I want to be the kind of person who can support others the way I've been supported, and I hope that by sharing my story, I can help someone else feel less alone in their own journey. Financially, I know it's tight, but I'm learning to be more responsible with what I have and to prioritize what really matters. I'm not where I want to be yet, but I'm proud of the progress I've made and the person I'm becoming.

Interviewer: In total, how much did your household make in the past month?

Jerome Williams: In total, our household made around $1,800 last month. That's mostly from my part-time job at the nonprofit, plus what my parents contribute. It's not a lot, but it covers the basics—rent, groceries, transportation, and my GED classes. I know it's not enough to save for the future or even to have much extra, but I'm trying to be responsible with what we have. I've learned that money isn't everything, but it does help when you're trying to build something better. I just hope that one day, I can earn more and give my sister the opportunities I didn't have. Until then, I'm just focused on making sure we don't fall behind and that I keep moving forward, even if it's one step at a time.

Interviewer: Tell me more about your workplace. How long have you been at your current job? How would you describe the benefits that come with your job? (This could include things like health benefits, paid time off, vacation, and sick time.)

Jerome Williams: I've been at Youth Forward for about a year now, and honestly, it's been one of the most important jobs I've ever had. The benefits aren't the typical ones you see in bigger companies—no health insurance or paid vacation days—but what they do offer is something more valuable. They give me purpose, a sense of belonging, and the chance to make a real difference in someone else's life. The biggest benefit, I think, is the support system. The people here, from the directors to the other volunteers, they're like family. They don't just see me as an employee—they see me as someone who's trying to grow, who's trying to do better. And that makes all the difference. I know I'm not making a lot of money, but I feel like I'm investing in something bigger than myself. I'm investing in the kids who come through here, in the community, and in the person I want to become.

Interviewer: How would you describe your relationships at work? (How is your relationship with your manager or boss? How are your relationships with your coworkers?)

Jerome Williams: My relationships at work are pretty much like family. My manager, Mr. Thompson, he's been like a father figure to me. He's the one who really saw something in me when I was at my lowest, and he didn't give up on me. He's always pushing me to be better, but he also knows when to give me space. He's strict when he needs to be, but he's fair and he cares. And the coworkers—Marcus is definitely my brother, but there are others too, like Lisa and Carlos, who've been there for me when I needed support. We all have our own struggles, but we lift each other up. It's not just about the work we do; it's about the trust we've built with each other. I feel like I can be myself here, without judgment, and that's something I didn't think I'd ever find in a workplace. It's not perfect, but it's real, and that's what makes it special.

Interviewer: Tell me about how predictable your work schedule is. How would you describe your job in terms of flexibility with your hours?

Jerome Williams: My work schedule is pretty predictable, but there's still some flexibility depending on what we need to get done. I usually start at 9 a.m. and finish at 3 p.m., but sometimes I'll stay a little later if there's an event or if I need to catch up on paperwork. The nice thing is, I don't have to be in the office at a specific time every day—most of the time, I can plan my day around my classes and family responsibilities. That flexibility has been a huge help, especially since I'm still working on my GED and trying to be there for my sister. I know some jobs don't offer that kind of freedom, but I'm grateful for it. It makes it easier to balance everything without feeling like I'm constantly running behind.

Interviewer: Overall, how do you feel about your financial situation?

Jerome Williams: Overall, I feel like my financial situation is a constant balancing act, but I'm trying not to let it define me. I know I'm not where I want to be, but I'm proud of how I've managed to keep things going without falling apart. I don't have a lot, but I've learned to be resourceful and to make the most of what I have. I've also learned that money isn't the only measure of success—what matters more is the progress I'm making, the people I'm helping, and the life I'm building for myself and my sister. I know it's going to take time, and there will be days when it feels impossible, but I'm not giving up. I believe in the work I'm doing, and I believe that one day, I'll be able to look back and see how far I've come.

Going through the questions about my bills, savings, and work hours made me realize how much I've grown in understanding the value of stability and responsibility. I used to take things for granted, thinking I could just keep pushing through without really planning or saving. But now, I see how important it is to be mindful of my finances, even when things are tight. I'm learning that it's not about having a lot—it's about being smart with what I have and making choices that support my future, my sister, and the people I care about. I'm still figuring things out, but I'm proud of the progress I've made, even if it's small. I know I have a long way to go, but I'm no longer afraid to face the challenges ahead.

Interviewer: Did your mom/dad work for pay for at least a year while you were growing up?

Jerome Williams: Yes, both my mom and dad worked for pay while I was growing up. My mom had a full-time job as a nurse's aide at a local hospital, and my dad worked in a professional field—something with data analysis or project management, I think. They both worked pretty much every day, even when things were tough. I remember seeing my mom come home exhausted after long shifts, and my dad would sometimes stay up late working on projects from home. They never complained about the work, even when they were stressed or tired. I think that's why I always felt like I had to be responsible, even when I wasn't making the best choices. They worked hard to give me opportunities, and I know I let them down a lot. But looking back, I see how much they sacrificed for me and my sister. I just hope I can pay that forward somehow, even if it's in small ways.

Interviewer: What was their job? What kind of work did they do? What were their most important activities or duties?

Jerome Williams: My mom worked as a nurse's aide at a local hospital, and her most important duties were helping patients with their daily needs—assisting them with bathing, feeding, and making sure they were comfortable. She also kept track of their vital signs and reported any changes to the nurses on duty. It was a tough job, especially during night shifts, but she always made sure to take care of her patients first. My dad worked in data analysis for a consulting firm—he spent most of his time crunching numbers, creating reports, and helping businesses make decisions based on the data he analyzed. He was pretty good at his job, but he never talked much about it. I remember seeing him sit at his desk late into the night, focused on his work, even when he was tired. Both of them had demanding jobs, but they always made sure to be there for me and my sister. I think that's why I felt like I had to be responsible, even when I wasn't making the best choices. They worked hard to give me opportunities, and I know I let them down a lot. But looking back, I see how much they sacrificed for me and my sister. I just hope I can pay that forward somehow, even if it's in small ways.

Interviewer: What kind of place did they work for? What kind of business was them? What did they make or do?

Jerome Williams: My mom worked at a local hospital, and it was one of those places where the staff was always running around, trying to keep up with the needs of the patients. It wasn't the biggest hospital in the city, but it was a place where people really cared. She was part of the support team, so she didn't have the same responsibilities as the doctors or nurses, but she was still essential. She made sure patients were comfortable, helped them with meals, and sometimes just sat with them when they were feeling alone. I remember seeing her come home with her uniform still on, her feet swollen from standing all day, and her voice always tired but steady. My dad worked for a consulting firm, one of those places where people wore suits and spent most of their time in meetings or hunched over computers. He was good at his job, but he never really talked about it much. I think he was one of those people who preferred to keep his work separate from his home life. I remember seeing him come home late, sometimes with a cup of coffee and a look like he was still thinking about something. Both of them had jobs that weren't easy, but they never made me feel like I had to be perfect or that I had to earn their love. They just worked hard, and I think that's what I learned from them—how to keep going, even when things are tough.

Interviewer: We all have hopes about what our future will look like. Imagine yourself a few years from now. Maybe you want your life to be the same in some ways as it is now. Maybe you want it to be different in some ways. What do you hope for?

Jerome Williams: A few years from now, I hope I'm still in this neighborhood, but not just surviving—I hope I'm thriving. I want to be the person who's not only helping kids like I used to be helped, but who's also making a real difference in the community. I see myself working full-time at Youth Forward, maybe even in a leadership role, where I can shape programs that truly support kids in need. I want to be the one who's there when they feel lost, just like I was once. I also hope I've finished my GED and maybe even started college, even if it's online or part-time. I want to have my own place, something small but stable, where I can be there for my sister and maybe even have a family of my own one day. But more than anything, I want to be someone who others can look up to—not because I have everything figured out, but because I keep showing up, even when it's hard. I want to be proof that no matter where you come from, you can change your life if you're willing to put in the work. That's what I'm working toward, and I know it's going to take time, but I'm ready for it.

Interviewer: What do you value the most in your life?

Jerome Williams: What I value the most in my life is the people who keep me grounded, especially my sister. She's the reason I keep pushing forward, even when things get tough. I also value the chance to make a difference in someone else's life, whether it's through my work at the nonprofit or just being there for someone who needs support. I think what I value most is the idea of growth—knowing that I can keep learning, keep changing, and keep trying to be better, even if it takes time. I don't value things like material success or status; I value the relationships I build, the progress I make, and the strength it takes to keep going when you're not sure where you're headed. I think that's what matters most—being real, being present, and being there for the people who matter.

Going through the interview questions about my work, financial situation, and relationships at my job made me reflect on how far I've come and how much I still have to grow. It's been a long journey, but I'm proud of the person I'm becoming. I used to feel like I wasn't good enough, like I didn't deserve to be where I am. But now, I see that I've made it this far by showing up, even when it was hard. My job at Youth Forward isn't just about the work I do—it's about the people I've met along the way, the support I've received, and the impact I'm trying to make. I know I'm not perfect, and I know I still have a lot to learn, but I'm no longer afraid to face the challenges ahead. I'm learning to value the small victories, the progress I've made, and the strength it takes to keep going. I'm still figuring things out, but I'm ready to keep moving forward, one step at a time.

Going through this complete interview and life story has been a journey of reflection, growth, and acceptance. It's been hard to relive the moments of my past—those times when I made poor choices, when I felt lost, and when I didn't believe in myself. But it's also been a chance to see how far I've come, to recognize the strength it took to get back on my feet, and to understand that my story isn't just about the mistakes I made, but about the people who helped me through them. I've learned that change doesn't happen overnight, and that healing is a process, not a quick fix. I've also come to appreciate the small victories—the days I show up for my sister, the times I stick to my routine, the moments I choose to be kind to myself instead of harsh. I used to think I had to be perfect to be worth something, but now I know that being human is enough. I'm still learning, still growing, but I'm proud of the person I'm becoming. I hope that by sharing my story, I can help someone else feel less alone in their own journey, and that I can be the kind of person who shows others that no matter where you come from, you can change your life if you're willing to put in the work.
